appearances.snippet: joining me now is democratic congressman adam smith. he is the ranking member on the house armed services committee. when you see the president's warning on social media to iran, he used the words locked and loaded. do you take this as a threat that the president is considering a strike of some sort? >> yeah, well, it is that threat, to be sure. but with president trump, you never know. i mean, he throws a lot of threats out and a lot of different directions. he carries out a lot of them, but a lot of them, he just sort of forgets about. so it's hard to say, but it is dangerous and worrisome. i don't think anyone in the united states wants to go to war with iran, and that is what president trump is proposing with this threat. and look, i have an enormous amount of sympathy for the iranian people. i think reforms in the iranian regime are desperately needed. but a lesson that we should have learned in the last 25 years is that regime change and getting involved in other countries, internal politics is never as easy as it looks. however g

appearances.snippet: these are members like senator tim kaine and senator and congressman adam smith, both of whom have had. both of them have said that they feel lied to by this administration. and so as much as it's a good thing that the administration is coming in and briefing members, this is something that members have been clamoring for for days since this initial action in venezuela over the weekend. at the same time, the underpinning of it is that there's deep mistrust, especially from democrats, toward the administration. i think more broadly, if you zoom out the questions that members had going in and we're starting to see them trickle out. so we'll see what questions actually got answered were largely about what is the plan next, not just in terms of oil that the president has centered as part of this conversation, but also in terms of are there other military actions in other countries that this administration is going to try to push toward? there are questions about cuba. there are questions about panama, colombia. and that's just keeping it within this hemisphere, because you ana, led off thi

appearances.title: Britain's Newsroom : GBN : January 12, 2026 9:30am-12:01pm GMT
appearances.snippet: chairing one of britain's biggest online retailers, helping out the adam smith institute and of courseoth here in the uk and internationally. but i also know a thing or two about growing up in a country that is fundamentally broken, riven by sectarian strife, economic depression and cratering living standards. so i have decided not to stand by and watch that happen to the country that took me in and let me live my british dream. not when so many of my countrymen are instead living the way. the waking nightmare of keir starmer's two tier britain. so i stand here with the leader of my new party to offer my help and my insights to the dynamic, confident team that nigel farage is building and to urge others from across all the other parties and the many millions who until now felt that politics isn't for them to come and join us, come and join us. you know, britain is broken. you know it needs reform. since leaving parliament, i have been reflecting on the successes and failures of my old party's time in government. i now rue the timidity, even at times the weakness with which we try to de

appearances.title: Morning Joe : MSNOW : January 15, 2026 3:00am-7:00am PST
appearances.snippet: military deployment since august in the caribbean cost taxpayers and essentially representative adam smithhe ranking member. he's from washington state on the house armed services committee. he went on the record and said, we've been trying to get this these numbers for months, and we're not getting anything. senator jack reed, he's the top democrat on the senate armed services committee, the same thing. and this is just very unusual. the biden administration didn't like giving this information out, but they did. congress appropriates this money. this is the direct oversight committee for the pentagon. and in terms of numbers, they estimate that this could could have cost so far at least $1 billion. both the boat strikes the build up in august, and then this operation that was carried out that resulted in the arrest of maduro. but they just don't know. and this is congress power of the purse, the oversight. and they don't have this information. the pentagon says we did give congress this information. the democrats say that's not true. when i asked for the numbers, if you've given it to the

appearances.title: Breakfast with Stephen and Anne : GBN : January 10, 2026 6:00am-10:00am GMT
appearances.snippet: let's talk to the director of public affairs at the adam smith institute, max marlow, and political commentatored. a very good morning to both of you. max. let's hear from you first, because why shouldn't it be banned if it's if it's wrong basically, and most people would feel it's morally wrong and offensive, why not ban it. >> so well. good morning. firstly i mean so x has about 23 million users in the uk at the moment. and the concern is, is, is mainly to do with the fact that you can basically tag the ai bots known as grock and have it basically manipulate images. and i agree with nigel farage and actually, you know, the vast, vast majority of people that this is completely wrong and i don't think, you know, limiting it to, you know, to paid users is going to fix this problem. the uk actually needs to enforce its own laws on what we call csam or, you know, child sexually and exploitative material and, you know, actually put safeguards in place. but i think overall banning the platform is just the wrong move. the vast, vast majority of people who use x are using it completely lawfully. they
